citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
An elderly male Fennec fox located off exhibit in the barn is observed to have a large mass on it's left ear causing the ear
to droop, head to tilt and the fox to shake his head. The owner stated that this fox is known to have had a hematoma in
the past that required draining. He stated that the veterinarian had told him he was allowed to drain the hematoma
himself. There are no records to indicate this fox has recently been examined or treated. In addition, there are no written
instructions from the veterinarian for the management and treatment of this fox. The fox shall me examined by the
veterinarian and appropriate care provided. Records shall be maintained documenting the condition, care and treatment.
Correct by May 5, 2023.
A second elderly male Fennec fox located in the same enclosure is observed squinting with it right eye. USDA did not
observe the eye completely open at any point during the inspection. Squinting may be an indication of the presence of a
foreign body, injury or illness. There are no records present indicating the the condition was previously observed or
treated. The Fennec fox shall be examined by the veterinarian and appropriate treatment provided. Records shall be
maintained documenting the condition, care and treatment. Correct by May 5, 2023.

The Fennec fox enclosure has excess accumulation of old kibble and feces on the ground. There are no clear areas for
the foxes to pass that would allow them to remain uncontaminated by the accumulation. This enclosure does not appear
to have been cleaned in a few days. Improper cleaning and accumulations of old feed and feces can lead to insect
infestation and vermin which may result in illness. The enclosure shall be cleaned at a frequency that will prevent
accumulations of old feed and feces to protect the foxes from illness. Correct by May 6, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
An elderly male Fennec fox located off exhibit in the barn is observed to have a large mass on it's left ear causing the ear 
to droop, head to tilt and the fox to shake his head.  The owner stated that this fox is known to have had a hematoma in 
the past that required draining.  He stated that the veterinarian had told him he was allowed to drain the hematoma 
himself.  There are no records to indicate this fox has recently been examined or treated.  In addition, there are no written 
instructions from the veterinarian for the management and treatment of this fox.   The fox shall me examined by the 
veterinarian and appropriate care provided.  Records shall be maintained documenting the condition, care and treatment.  
Correct by May 5, 2023. 
 
A second elderly male Fennec fox located in the same enclosure is observed squinting with it right eye.  USDA did not 
observe the eye completely open at any point during the inspection.  Squinting may be an indication of the presence of a 
foreign body, injury or illness.  There are no records present indicating the the condition was previously observed or 
treated. The Fennec fox shall be examined by the veterinarian and appropriate treatment provided.  Records shall be 
maintained documenting the condition, care and treatment.  Correct by May 5, 2023. 
3.131(a)

Sanitation. 
The Fennec fox enclosure has excess accumulation of old kibble and feces on the ground. There are no clear areas for 
the foxes to pass that would allow them to remain uncontaminated by the accumulation. This enclosure does not appear 
to have been cleaned in a few days.  Improper cleaning and accumulations of old feed and feces can lead to insect 
infestation and vermin which may result in illness.  The enclosure shall be cleaned at a frequency that will prevent 
accumulations of old feed and feces to protect the foxes from illness.  Correct by May 6, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
